site_name: CHARLES Mc GINNIS & DEBBI Mc GINNIS

citations.narrative:
The Record of Acquisition of Dogs on Hand (APHIS form 7005) was missing the addresses of the people from whom 6
dogs were purchased. Properly completed acquisition records are necessary for identification of dogs to facilitate record-
keeping requirements for inventory, disposition, transport, and healthcare. The licensee must update the Record of
Acquisition and maintain the record on a regular basis so that it always has accurate information regarding acquisition,
identification, and disposition for all dogs. TO BE CORRECTED BY NOVEMBER 10, 2023.

An enclosure in the whelping building housing two adult Lhaso Apso had excessive amounts of fecal material and urine
on the floor. An outdoor enclosure housing 4 weaned Corgi puppies had an excessive amount of feces. The licensee
stated that it had been 2 days since he had picked up feces. There was also excessive dirt and grime on the outside of
the door of the enclosure housing the 2 Lhaso Apso as well as an enclosure housing one adult Weimaraner and an
enclosure housing an adult Dachshund. Feces, dirt, and grime can harbor organisms that can affect the health of the
dogs. The licensee must ensure that all enclosures are spot-cleaned for feces daily and that cleaning and sanitization are
done as frequently as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation of feces, to prevent soiling of the dogs, and to reduce
disease hazards.

The open supply of dog food was being stored in a leakproof container in an open shed; however, the lid was bent to the
point that it no longer fit on the container. The dog food was exposed even with the lid sitting on top of the container.
Unprotected dog food can be contaminated by pests such as insects, birds, and mammals. The licensee must ensure that
open supplies of food are kept in leakproof containers with tightly-fitted lids to prevent contamination and spoilage. TO BE
CORRECTED BY NOVEMBER 4, 2023.

An adult male Boxer, an adult male Weimeraner, and two adult Lhaso Apso did not have sufficient bedding in their
outdoor shelters. There was straw in each shelter, but not enough to cover the floor. At the time of the inspection, the
ambient temperature was over 50 degrees F; however, according to the website for the National Weather Service, the
temperature the night before this inspection was below 35 degrees F. Inadequate bedding can result in the dogs
becoming too cold, possibly resulting in stress, pain, frostbite, and medical conditions from being unable to control their
body temperature. The licensee must provide clean, dry bedding material in outdoor shelters whenever the ambient
temperature is below 50 degrees F and must provide additional clean, dry bedding material when the ambient
temperature is 35 degrees F or lower. TO BE CORRECTED FROM THIS POINT FORWARD ON NOVEMBER 2, 2023.

An adult male Boxer did not have water to drink at the time of the inspection. The water receptacle was overturned inside
the shelter and there was no water residue inside the shelter or inside the receptacle. When the licensee filled the
receptacle with water the dog drank almost continuously for about a minute, indicating intense thirst. A lack of water can
be painful, stressful, and can lead to medical conditions from dehydration. The licensee must ensure that all dogs have
continual access to potable water at all times. TO BE CORRECTED FROM THIS POINT FORWARD ON NOVEMBER 2,
2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.75(a)(1)(i) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The Record of Acquisition of Dogs on Hand (APHIS form 7005) was missing the addresses of the people from whom 6 
dogs were purchased. Properly completed acquisition records are necessary for identification of dogs to facilitate record-
keeping requirements for inventory, disposition, transport, and healthcare. The licensee must update the Record of 
Acquisition and maintain the record on a regular basis so that it always has accurate information regarding acquisition, 
identification, and disposition for all dogs. TO BE CORRECTED BY NOVEMBER 10, 2023. 
3.1(c)(3)  Repeat
   
Housing facilities, general. 
An enclosure in the whelping building housing two adult Lhaso Apso had excessive amounts of fecal material and urine 
on the floor. An outdoor enclosure housing 4 weaned Corgi puppies had an excessive amount of feces. The licensee 
stated that it had been 2 days since he had picked up feces. There was also excessive dirt and grime on the outside of 
the door of the enclosure housing the 2 Lhaso Apso as well as an enclosure housing one adult Weimaraner and an 
enclosure housing an adult Dachshund. Feces, dirt, and grime can harbor organisms that can affect the health of the 
dogs. The licensee must ensure that all enclosures are spot-cleaned for feces daily and that cleaning and sanitization are 
done as frequently as necessary to prevent excessive accumulation of feces, to prevent soiling of the dogs, and to reduce 
disease hazards. 
3.1(e) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
The open supply of dog food was being stored in a leakproof container in an open shed; however, the lid was bent to the 
point that it no longer fit on the container. The dog food was exposed even with the lid sitting on top of the container. 
Unprotected dog food can be contaminated by pests such as insects, birds, and mammals. The licensee must ensure that 
open supplies of food are kept in leakproof containers with tightly-fitted lids to prevent contamination and spoilage. TO BE 
CORRECTED BY NOVEMBER 4, 2023. 
3.4(b)(4)

Outdoor housing facilities. 
An adult male Boxer, an adult male Weimeraner, and two adult Lhaso Apso did not have sufficient bedding in their 
outdoor shelters. There was straw in each shelter, but not enough to cover the floor. At the time of the inspection, the 
ambient temperature was over 50 degrees F; however, according to the website for the National Weather Service, the 
temperature the night before this inspection was below 35 degrees F. Inadequate bedding can result in the dogs 
becoming too cold, possibly resulting in stress, pain, frostbite, and medical conditions from being unable to control their 
body temperature. The licensee must provide clean, dry bedding material in outdoor shelters whenever the ambient 
temperature is below 50 degrees F and must provide additional clean, dry bedding material when the ambient 
temperature is 35 degrees F or lower. TO BE CORRECTED FROM THIS POINT FORWARD ON NOVEMBER 2, 2023. 
3.10(a)  Direct
   
Watering 
An adult male Boxer did not have water to drink at the time of the inspection. The water receptacle was overturned inside 
the shelter and there was no water residue inside the shelter or inside the receptacle. When the licensee filled the 
receptacle with water the dog drank almost continuously for about a minute, indicating intense thirst. A lack of water can 
be painful, stressful, and can lead to medical conditions from dehydration. The licensee must ensure that all dogs have 
continual access to potable water at all times. TO BE CORRECTED FROM THIS POINT FORWARD ON NOVEMBER 2, 
2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
